title: Fashion Shoot with a DIY Seamless Paper Dress
summary: Fashion photographer Lindsay Adler demonstrates a creative photoshoot featuring a dress made entirely from scraps of seamless paper. She explains her lighting strategy to emphasize the paper's texture, uses a V-flat for fill, and employs an optical spot to create a dynamic background pattern that mimics the dress design.

steps.action: Introduction to the concept of creating a fashion dress using scraps of seamless paper.
Select a background color. Lindsay chooses a dark gray to allow the subject to pop without visual distractions.
steps.tool: Savage Universal Fashion Gray Seamless Paper

steps.action: Set up the main light off to the side to rake across the subject and emphasize the texture of the paper dress.
steps.tool: Profoto D2, Extra Large Umbrella with Diffusion

steps.action: Introduce a white V-flat as a reflector to lift the shadows on the dark side of the face.
Add a second strobe with an optical spot and a 'searchlight' gobo to project a pattern onto the background that mimics the dress shapes.
steps.tool: Westcott Optical Spot, Searchlight Gobo, 24-70mm Lens

steps.action: Configure camera settings. Lindsay shoots at f/8 to keep the background pattern relatively sharp.
Select camera and lens. A zoom lens is used for flexibility in cropping and composition.
steps.tool: Canon EOS R5, Canon RF 24-105mm f/4 L IS

key_takeaways: Collaboration with artists can turn simple materials like scrap paper into high-fashion wardrobe pieces.
Side lighting is crucial for emphasizing texture and shape in monochromatic subjects.
Optical spots with specific gobos can be used to mirror the subject's geometry on the background.
Using a V-flat helps control contrast by lifting deep shadows created by directional main lighting.
Shooting at a higher f-stop (like f/8) keeps projected background patterns sharp and defined.
